tanks.notes: All tanks organic to 2nd New Zealand Division (4th Armoured Brigade). 51st Highland and 9th Australian are pure infantry divisions with NO organic tanks.

Ordnance QF 25-pounder.notes: 9 field regiments (51st: 3, 2nd NZ: 3, 9th Aus: 3), 24 guns each

Ordnance QF 6-pounder.notes: Primary AT weapon across all divisions

supply_logistics.supply_status: Excellent for offensive operations. XXX Corps as main assault force received priority supply allocation. Short supply lines from Alexandria (100-250km) provided substantial advantage. Forward supply dumps established for El Alamein offensive. Adequate stockpiles of ammunition, fuel, and water.

weather_environment.season_quarter: 1942-Q4 (October-December) - Autumn to early winter, optimal campaigning season
weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal plain and rocky desert (El Alamein position), firm ground for infantry operations

subordinate_units.notes: Elite combined-arms formation with 4th Armoured Brigade
Veteran siege warfare specialists from Tobruk

tactical_doctrine.role: Main breakthrough force for Second Battle of El Alamein. Methodical set-piece assault through heavily mined Axis defensive positions in northern sector. Infantry-led 'break-in' followed by armoured exploitation.
special_capabilities: Three elite Commonwealth infantry divisions with high morale
Night assault operations (Operation Lightfoot opening phase)
Infantry-tank cooperation with attached armoured brigades
Veteran troops with extensive desert warfare experience
tactical_innovations: Systematic 'crumbling' operations to reduce enemy positions
Coordinated night assault with compass bearings
Integration of New Zealand armoured brigade within infantry corps
known_issues: Infantry divisions lacking organic armour (except 2nd NZ)
Heavy casualties expected in assault through minefields
Coordination challenges across three national contingents
Limited mobility compared to armoured formations
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: All divisions fully acclimatized to desert conditions. Extensive water transport, sun compasses, dust protection, desert camouflage. Strong logistics tail for sustained operations.

operations.name: Second Battle of El Alamein (Operation Lightfoot)
operations.role: Main assault force - breakthrough in northern sector
operations.outcome: Decisive success - achieved breakthrough despite heavy casualties, destroyed Axis defensive line

operations.name: Kidney Ridge Battle
operations.role: 51st Highland Division assault and defense of vital ground

operations.name: Operation Supercharge
operations.role: 2nd NZ Division breakthrough for armoured exploitation
operations.outcome: Success - opened path for X Corps armour

historical_context.combat_effectiveness: Excellent. XXX Corps sustained approximately 6,000 casualties (12% of strength) but achieved all breakthrough objectives. Three divisions demonstrated high morale, aggressive tactics, and ability to sustain offensive operations under fire. New Zealand armoured brigade performed well in combined-arms role.

scenario_suitability: Second Battle of El Alamein (main breakthrough)
special_rules: High Morale (re-roll failed morale once per turn)
Combined Arms Coordination (+1 when infantry-armour-artillery coordinate)

source: Second Battle of El Alamein order of battle (Military History Database)
XXX Corps operations records (Imperial War Museums)
Lieutenant-General Oliver Leese command appointment (British Army records)
Subordinate division TO&E files (51st Highland, 2nd NZ, 9th Australian)
El Alamein battle analysis (multiple historical sources)
known_gaps: Corps-level HQ staff names (except corps commander)
Precise operational vs authorized equipment counts
validation.notes: Aggregated from three subordinate divisions: 51st Highland (17,850), 2nd NZ (16,500), 9th Australian (16,000). Personnel total includes ~700 corps HQ staff. Equipment totals summed from divisional files. XXX Corps was main breakthrough force at Second Battle of El Alamein, sustaining ~6,000 casualties but achieving decisive breakthrough in northern sector.
